svg.text:
In this model, two transmitters send messages with duration 1.0 periodically. The messages from Transmitter1 collide with every second message from Transmitter0, causing both messages to be lost.
If you change the SNRThresholdInDB parameter of the Receiver to 3 (3dB is a factor of two in power), then the messages from Transmitter0 will be successfully received despite the collision.
If you then move Transmitter1 closer to the Receiver, then every second message from Transmitter0 will again be lost.
Send messages every two seconds with duration equal to one second.
After a 2.5 second delay, send messages every four seconds with duration equal to one second

This receiver extracts the received power and message duration and feeds them into a CollisionDetector actor. This actor either ignores the message (if the received power is below the powerThreshold) or sends it to the received or collided output. It goes to the received output if the signal to interference ratio remains above SNRThresholdInDB for the entire duration of the message. Otherwise, it goes to the collided output. The rest of the actors are devoted to generating the displays.

property.name: text
property.value: Construct a plot with square pulses showing the received power over a time duration for each transmitter.

property.name: text
property.value: Construct a plot showing the times at which messages are received and lost.
